w:r.w:t: They will develop their vocabulary and also work on responding to simple questions requiring them to respond with some of their recent vocabulary words.
When applicable they should use adjectives to describe the clothing items.
and the plural forms of the words.

-branded opener slide that the teacher will display as the student enters the classroom.

Complete the sentence frame with the correct word:
using TPR (shoulder shrug for question, putting hand
Student responds either: “I see clothes,” or specific items of clothing depending on level.
Complete the sentence frame with the correct word:
Student repeats the word shoes several times.
Say and spell Shoes: s-h-o-e-s- shoes
Student writes the word on the screen or a piece of paper.
Visual Cue: Show students several pairs of shoes saying: “These are shoes.”
This can be fun with baby shoes, large shoes etc.
Show student shoes and non-examples, asking: “Are these shoes?”
Students responds: “Yes, these are shoes,” or “No, these are not shoes.”
Student circles image of a shoe (s)
and draws a line to the appropriate word.
show various single shoes saying “a shoe” and then multiple shoes saying “
This is a shoe,” or “These are shoes.”
Visual cue: alternate between one or two shoes
Extension: Have the student use adjectives to describe the shoes.
Fill in the blanks with the correct sight words: Shoe and shoes
Model on a white board or on the screen while asking the student to fill in the blanks.
Explain to students that two shoes together are referred to as a pair of shoes
If student has trouble review the difference between a shoe and two shoes.
Complete the sentence frame with the correct word:
Student repeats the word socks several times.
Say and spell socks: s-o-c-k-s- socks.
Student claps out the letters as they spell the word.
Visual Cue: Show students several pairs of shocks saying: “These are socks.”
This can be fun with small socks, crazy socks, holiday socks etc.
and say: “I wear socks” underlining each word. Student repeats.

Student reads the words: “clothes, shoes, socks, shoe, sock”
Model filling in the blank with another familiar word such as “water.” Either use a white board or the screen.
If student has trouble filling in the blanks help coach and correct.
Complete the sentence frame with the correct word:
Clap the letters while spelling hat.
Have the student clap the letters while spelling the word.
the student different kinds of hats or pictures of hats.
TPR: motion putting something on your head.
Read the sentence: “I wear a hat,”
using TPR of pointing toward yourself and putting on a real or virtual hat.
Student repeats while teacher underlines each word: “I wear a hat.”
Show the student different articles of clothing and hats asking: “Is it a hat?”
The student responds “Yes, it is a hat,” or “No, it is not a hat.”
Circle and say the correct sight words:
Visual cues: review the words: hat, sock, and shoe by showing students real objects, pictures or drawings.
Circle each item on the screen asking: “What is it?”
Complete the sentence frame with the correct word:
Write the word shirt on a screen.
Say and spell the word shirt: S-H-I-R-T: shirt
Have the student write the word several times on the screen or on a piece of paper.
Visual Cue: Show the student several shirts, or pictures of shirts.
TPR: Act like you are putting on a shirt, or pull on the sleeves of your own shirt.
Using TPR say: “I wear a shirt.”
As the student repeats: “I wear a shirt,” underline each word.
Show various items of clothing or circle on the screen asking: “Is this a shirt?”
The student responds “Yes, it is a shirt,” or “No, it is not a shirt.”
Student fills in the blanks while saying the words: sock, shirt, hat, shoe
Model filling in the word clothes from a previous activity.
Have the student fill in the blanks.
Coach the student if they are unsure.
a line from each word to the correct image.
Student reads “shoes, shoe, socks, sock, hat, shirt, clothes”
Model drawing lines from the correct picture to the correct word, choose one of the words or write one of your own.
Have the student say each word as they draw the line.
If they have trouble correct them and help guide toward the correct answer.
Draw items of clothing on the blank slide.
Identify color of clothing they like.
Ask what color shirt do you like to wear?
Visual cue: Take some time to review colors and show examples of colors.
making a heart with your hands.
